title: #If X==Y is true when both are not defined  use of -Wundef
body:
We ran into an issues with some of PX4 code where the construct !If X==Y is true when both are not defined.

For example:

//#define PIGS 1
//#define DOGS 2
# if (DOGS == PIGS)
# warning("DOGS == PIGS") // it is to a compiler
# else
# warning "DOGS != PIGS"
# endif

When then built with -Wundef to ferret out any others:

he consolidated results of the -Wundef:

warning: "**APPLE**" is not defined [-Wundef] APPLE
warning: "**EXCEPTIONS" is not defined [-Wundef] __EXCEPTIONS
warning: "__linux" is not defined [-Wundef] __linux
warning: "__linux**" is not defined [-Wundef] linux
warning: "_HAS_EXCEPTIONS" is not defined [-Wundef] _HAS_EXCEPTIONS
warning: "_WIN32" is not defined [-Wundef] _WIN32
warning: "_WIN64" is not defined [-Wundef] _WIN64
warning: "CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_AEROCORE" is not defined [-Wundef] CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_AEROCORE
warning: "CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_PX4FMU_V2" is not defined [-Wundef] CONFIG_ARCH_BOARD_PX4FMU_V2
warning: "CONFIG_NSOCKET_DESCRIPTORS" is not defined [-Wundef] CONFIG_NSOCKET_DESCRIPTORS
warning: "CONFIG_STM32_TIM1" is not defined [-Wundef] CONFIG_STM32_TIM1
warning: "CONFIG_STM32_TIM8" is not defined [-Wundef] CONFIG_STM32_TIM8
warning: "MULT_COUNT" is not defined [-Wundef] MULT_COUNT
warning: "STM32_NGTIMNDMA" is not defined [-Wundef] STM32_NGTIMNDMA
warning: "UAVCAN_DEBUG" is not defined [-Wundef] UAVCAN_DEBUG
warning: "UAVCAN_MEM_POOL_BLOCK_SIZE" is not defined [-Wundef] UAVCAN_MEM_POOL_BLOCK_SIZE
warning: "UAVCAN_STM32_CHIBIOS" is not defined [-Wundef] UAVCAN_STM32_CHIBIOS
warning: "UAVCAN_STM32_TIMER_NUMBER" is not defined [-Wundef] UAVCAN_STM32_TIMER_NUMBER

Need to 1) see if any of them are significant 
2) see if the warnings can be remedied with an alternate construct of #if defined(XYZ) #if XYZ==PQT .... #endif #endif or such.

title: MAVLink stream config
body: The stream config fails on recent NuttX, and we need spurious usleep calls on our current stable version. Worth inspecting what is going on there.

title: No RC and no datalink should trigger RTL
body: If there is no RC connected and all datalinks are lost, the UAV should go into RTL (or do anything else about that unhappy state). Currently it seems to stay in loiter after the mission is finished.

title: Pixhawk crashes connected to QGC over USB
body:
I checked out, cleanbuilt and flashed the latest PX4 firmware and the latest QGC. I connect  /dev/ttyACM0 and rc.usb is started and all works as expected.

Then after some minutes, the FMU locks up (RGBLED freezes) and QGC reports connection lost.

title: Ashtech GPS driver issues
body:
@dyeldandi I missed something in the review that we need to fix immediately: This comparison here is absolutely not safe:
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.cpp#L181

Please use the proper field from the NMEA message instead. Here is some background information why this should not be done (also you should never assume special meaning of coordinates - 0, 0, 0 is a valid position off the coast of Africa, and drivers must not make assumptions about the use of the system).

See here for a solid discussion of the issue: http://randomascii.wordpress.com/2012/02/25/comparing-floating-point-numbers-2012-edition/

In general:
- Never use special floating-point values as flags. Just don't do it. Passing extra arguments to a function is cheap by comparison, and has the added benefit of being much clearer.
- Never perform equality comparisons on floating-point values. Code that assumes it can is fundamentally broken and needs to be fixed.

```
/Users/user/src/Firmware/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.h:71:35: warning: "/*" within comment [-Wcomment]
/Users/user/src/Firmware/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.cpp: In member function 'int ASHTECH::handle_message(int)':
/Users/user/src/Firmware/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.cpp:181:15: warning: comparing floating point with == or != is unsafe [-Wfloat-equal]
/Users/user/src/Firmware/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.cpp:181:31: warning: comparing floating point with == or != is unsafe [-Wfloat-equal]
/Users/user/src/Firmware/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.cpp:181:47: warning: comparing floating point with == or != is unsafe [-Wfloat-equal]
/Users/user/src/Firmware/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.cpp:283:15: warning: comparing floating point with == or != is unsafe [-Wfloat-equal]
/Users/user/src/Firmware/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.cpp:283:31: warning: comparing floating point with == or != is unsafe [-Wfloat-equal]
/Users/user/src/Firmware/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.cpp:283:47: warning: comparing floating point with == or != is unsafe [-Wfloat-equal]
/Users/user/src/Firmware/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.cpp: In member function 'virtual int ASHTECH::receive(unsigned int)':
/Users/user/src/Firmware/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.cpp:464:11: warning: declaration of 'count' shadows a member of 'this' [-Wshadow]
/Users/user/src/Firmware/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.cpp: In member function 'virtual int ASHTECH::configure(unsigned int&)':
/Users/user/src/Firmware/src/drivers/gps/ashtech.cpp:603:85: warning: comparison between signed and unsigned integer expressions [-Wsign-compare]
```

title: UAVCAN driver task priority
body: @hsteinhaus, the issue of UAVCAN communication latencies we investigated recently (caused by incorrect task priority configuration) causes severe sensor measurement delays which will make some UAVCAN-interfaced sensors perform poorer. I suggest to increase the UAVCAN task priority to `SCHED_PRIORITY_ACTUATOR_OUTPUTS` per your  proposition, despite that fact that it breaks APM arming at the moment. Anyway the arming problem is likely going to need a solution unrelated to task priority settings.

title: pitch rate setpoint NaN
body:
This showed up after we can have zero airspeed (with decent calibration) - might be unrelated, but noteworthy.

Note that the excessive printing resulted in a stack overflow. So the printing here should be made conditional to a debug variable and default to off. I actually found out while looking at set points in QGC.

```
fw_att_control: pitch_u NaN, _yaw_ctrl.get_desired_rate() 0.0000, airspeed 0.0000, airspeed_scaling 1.5385, roll_sp 0.0000, pitch_sp 0.0000, _roll_ctrl.get_desired_rate() 0.1842, _pitch_ctrl.get_desired_rate() NaN att_sp.roll_body 0.0000
```

title: Timeout waiting for data when flashing
body:
We're seeing more and more timeout waiting for data when flashing using the console and the px_uploader.py. Generally a second try after a power-cycle works.

It would be nice to determine the cause of this and fix it.

```
erase...
program...
ERROR: timeout waiting for data
```

It feels like uavcan stuff is built every time you build even though no change has been made to it.

Probably needs fixing in the makefile.

This commit here:
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/commit/90a5ae1afd25e5e31d269f0d0f5e5052f068d0b1

Causes the startup to block if the fw_pos_control_l1 controller is started. I suspect its related to the BlockParam interface (or mTECS). There is a second parameter there which is of a special type.

Identified in #1204

@thomasgubler @jgoppert This is something we want to fix quickly, as it may have implications on the overall BlockParam usage. I can't see what would be wrong within mTECS.

First problem is caused by the addition of mavlink_fd to arming_state_transition. Just needs to pass a 0 for no fd. 

Second is caused by the removal of MAIN_STATE_AUTO which is beyond my knowledge to fix. StateMachineHelperTest::mainStateTransitionTest needs to be updated to the new auto states.

```
nsh> ls -l /fs/microsd
/fs/microsd:
 -rw-rw-rw-    4096 ._.Trashes
 -rw-rw-rw-     221 bootlog.txt
*** FMU suspended ***
```

title: Repeating "DATA LINK LOST" when connected via USB
body:
When connecting to autopilot via USB (telemetry module also connected to autopilot, but no link) commander reports:

```
[12:42:09.135 - COMP:50] Info: Audio message: CRITICAL: DATA LINK LOST
[12:42:09.986 - COMP:50] Info: Audio message: data link regained
[12:42:10.132 - COMP:50] Info: Audio message: CRITICAL: DATA LINK LOST
[12:42:10.970 - COMP:50] Info: Audio message: data link regained
[12:42:11.185 - COMP:50] Info: Audio message: CRITICAL: DATA LINK LOST
[12:42:11.968 - COMP:50] Info: Audio message: data link regained
```

Because two mavlink instances publish different telemetry status. @julianoes, @thomasgubler, @LorenzMeier, any ideas how to fix this? In general case we may have multiple telemetry links (for redundancy) and at least on one working link should be enough.

I have some ideas:
- Add channel ID to `telemetry status` topic and track status for each link independently, but this will require some more code (storing timestamps for each link) and not beautiful from uORB point of view.
- Add multiple `telemetry status` topics (up to 4 or 7?), one for each mavlink channel, as for e.g. `actuator_conrols_X`. This is more clean solution but will require much more subscriptions/publications, that are expensive.
- When publishing telemetry status from mavlink check previous heartbeat timestamp and don't overwrite if new value is less. Hacky and ugly, but simple way to workaround the bug.

Also it would be good to have feedback check, i.e. on autopilot side check timestamp of last heartbeat received by GS, to make sure that link works in two-ways.

body: @AndreasAntener This is to track the negative spikes you were experiencing. I believe its a sign conversion issue that shows only on your setup because of the specifics of the sensor offset / voltage of your sensor. I would appreciate if we could get to the bottom of this 8).

title: Manual control setpoint pitch is inverted
body:
Pitch is [commonly defined](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7e/Rollpitchyawplain.png) as the righthand rotation around the y axis. Any variable (especially those which are used for inter-app communication) should adhere to this standard.

In the current master branch the field `pitch` of [manual_control_setpoint_s](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/uORB/topics/manual_control_setpoint.h) is inverted.

It seems that the change was introduced with commit 1d5f62d890d1d85cef5e0f8e282d8e9e70717d46 [starting from here.](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/commit/1d5f62d890d1d85cef5e0f8e282d8e9e70717d46#diff-b2cdb687c37812923ec65dc8fc767506L1400)

Before the commit the pitch value was mapped from the RC value with:

```
/*
* pitch input - stick down is negative, but stick down is pitching up (pos) in NED,
 * so reverse sign.
*/
manual_control.pitch = limit_minus_one_to_one(-1.0f * _rc.chan[_rc.function[PITCH]].scaled);
```

afterwards/now it is mapped with

```
manual_control.pitch = get_rc_value(PITCH, -1.0, 1.0);
```

so the previous correct sign change got lost.

Because the current state is confusing and wrong we have to either _rename_ the name of the variables in manual_control_setpoint_s or we have to _revert the sign change_. I am in favor of reverting the sign change.

I found the following commits related to the above change (directly after 1d5f62d890d1d85cef5e0f8e282d8e9e70717d46 in the commit history): 6f38ed3b4b6f266098d0616b6bd3c18ffe082755 e2ac5222d812bdbfaf33fc2d320ee22ab861d433 ef8b97437342401a464bcc844d6c347c33919d73

If `target_component == MAV_COMP_ID_ALL` then command will be sent back, it's not good idea. Need to find correct solution, but as hotfix we can just skip such commands here.

This happened with yaw SP at 180 degrees and -150 degrees.
Yaw SPs from 0 to 179 were fine.

NAV_LOITER_RAD

- FMUv2
- FrSky Rx with Tx on
- Flightgear HIL with QGC (no_portconfig)

Now it seems to trigger RC loss and quickly after RC regained whenever the load on the desktop/host computer is high or it quickly "freezes".

Any ideas how this can creep into the RC check?

title: Flightgear HIL broken

HIL stopped working for me, potentially since the merge of mavlink2.

Startup works as intended and I can arm using RC. However, in manual mode, I have no control, so the plane just jumps and dives right into the ground.

title: Support mission mode without Mission for FW
body: Switching to AUTO MISSION currently leads to a dive if no mission has been set.

title: Accel calibration on FMUv1 complains about memory
body:
Steps to reproduce: 
Startup with Quad startup script (F330)

Trying to calibrate Mag using QGC:
    mag calibration: started
    don't move system
    ERROR: out of memory

On FMUv1
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/commit/243a28ff8b7643edeea57640ce2ce4db5a40cead

title: Invalid formating in param set
body:
It looks like format for new parameter value is integer, it's not correct, e.g.:

nsh> param set MC_ROLLRATE_P 0.17
  MC_ROLLRATE_P: curr: 0.1000 -> new: 0

should be:
  MC_ROLLRATE_P: curr: 0.1000 -> new: 0.1700

It's just output formatting, i.e. not critical, but anyway.

title: Bug when using getopt()
body:
Just found very dangerous bug in getopt using:
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/systemcmds/pwm/pwm.c#L158

We must not exit from options parsing loop here (errx called from usage()), because it will leave global getopt variables in wrong state and next getopt() call, even from another application will fail.

Need to set some error flag and exit after parsing all options.
Also need to inspect all getopt usages for this bug.

title: PX4IO upgrade failed with autostart script 1001
body:
If autostart script 1001 (quadrotor HIL) selected (I suspect it's common for all HILs) and IO should be upgraded, upgrade will fail and FMUv2 will go to infinite reboot loop.

[HIL] setup done, running 
<px4io> io_reg_get(0,0,1): data error -1
[px4io] protocol/firmware mismatch
px4io: driver init failed
px4io: not started
PX4IO CRC failure 
px4io: px4io is not started, still attempting upgrade
[PX4IO] using firmware from /etc/extras/px4io-v2_default.bin
[PX4IO] found bootloader revision: 4
[PX4IO] erase...
[PX4IO] programming 54060 bytes...
position_estimator_inav: baro offs: -99.45
[PX4IO] program failed
<px4io> io_reg_get(0,0,1): data error -1
[px4io] protocol/firmware mismatch
px4io: driver init failed
PX4IO restart failed

title: Missing rc.error
body:
If PX4IO not installed rcS script fails at this line:
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/ROMFS/px4fmu_common/init.d/rcS#L189
because rc.error doesn't exist. Somebody forgot to add it to commit?

title: Magnetometer calibration param reset SD card
body:
Accel params written
Magnetometer calibration -> param write

Params erased

title: px4_simple_app: crash when app returns
body:
This issue relates to this email thread:
https://groups.google.com/d/msg/px4users/nRxxc2HrzO4/lF3tDS-_drEJ

Basically, when the px4_simple_app returns after printing some values instead of looping forever, it sometimes crashes the FMU.

The issue can be reproduced using this commit 6d17af30fbc57e256e46d9bcdb02d63e1311d432


title: In-air restore doesn't work for multirotors
body:
Trying the following on FMUv2 with F330 autostart script (10):
- Disable safety
- Arm system
- Reset FMU with button

=> FMU beeps startup tune and then SOSOSOS..., only green LED, RGB led is off; IO blinks red and blue, PWM output = disarmed

title: param save in commander can be rejected
body:
The param save in the commander app sometimes (on FMUv1 and FMUv2) refuses to save params with this error:

```
commander_low_prio: opening '/fs/microsd/params' for writing failed: Too many open files
[cmd] parameters save error
[cmd] command failed: 245
```

The commandline 'param save' command still works then, though. So a file system issue can be ruled out, also SPI vs SDIO (DMA) seem to be unrelated. The issue is frequent enough, but no known path exists to reproduce. It occurs since param writes were moved to the low-prio command handling thread.

title: command line options
body:
the usb port is protocol wise dead. the imu is not accessable at all.
only a complete reflash will help.

the underlaying issue is:

mavlink start -b 115200-d /dev/ttyACM0

a small typing error :-)

title: Strange GPS EPV values when no lock on UBX
body: In mavlink plotter in qgroundcontrol GPS_RAW_INT.epv travels from 0 to 65535 linearry when no lock. When locked values are normal. Using UBX GPS module. Looks like a bug in ublox or ubx driver or mavlink. Need to check this.

title: Yaw setpoint in AUTO
body: Need to check yaw setpoint initialization in AUTO. It should be set for each waypoint, but we should not change it on AUTO | TAKEOFF.

title: Mag calibration can crash FMUv1
body: Sometimes when the mag calibration command is sent via mavlink, the FMU crashes. I have only observed this bug on FMU v1 so it might have something to do with the hmc5883 driver.

title: ubx gps parser draws 25% CPU after latest changes
body: The ubx gps parser process draws 25% CPU load after the last change set.

title: Review I2C changes introduced by recent NuttX merge in master
body: First testing suggests that although I2C operation is in general stable, some defective cases previously handled are now slipping through the error handling.

title: Inf / NaN handling
body: NuttX currently has in some cases issues with printing INF / NaN values (prints a lot of zeros or RAM content). This is not a PX4 Firmware issue, but still needs to be addressed soon, as more and more code is contributed where developers are not aware that they need to work around this by testing with isfinite() the value of the float/double before printing it.

title: The latest NuttX merge (in pull request #68) ruins incremental builds
body: The latest NuttX merge from pull request #68 ruins incremental builds on my machine. Still investigating, but quite annoying.

title: NullMixer not occupying one output slot as intended
body:
Loading a NullMixer from a file (Z:) does not produce an error, the resulting mixer group however does not assign a slot for it. The FMU_AET and FMU_delta mixers only report three mixers loaded, instead of four.

Using a nullmixer to offset the motor output to servo channel 4 has its value, as it simplifies HIL setups. It would be therefore nice to fix this functionality.

title: EEPROM init sometimes fails
body: Previously we had auto-reboot code in place to resolve this. This happens here and then and prevents the board from startup / reading params. A reset (not a power cycle) resolves the issue.

title: EEPROM erase fails permanently on one board
MS5611 init sometimes fails
body: The MS5611 init some times fails. Rebooting the board (not powering down, just resetting the M4) does resolve the issue. At least for headless setups we might consider adding a reboot on failure option, since we know this is a recoverable error. This of course will be confusing if the board is constantly rebooting, as long as that behavior is however part of the startup script, its a minor issue, since users will be able to sanity-check without the script.

title: Low-level init falls over sometimes if RC TX is on
body: Looks like a race condition in the RC input capture initialization, if the RC is on the low-level init can fall over. Not reproducible at all if the TX is off. This is probably the first thing we would like to resolve currently.

title: EEPROM erase command hangs
body: This needs more debugging / testing, but at cb57fdb I got a board in a state where the eeprom erase command consistently crashed the board / NSH. Will get back to it ASAP with JTAG.

title: MS5611 reads occur too fast
body:
Under some circumstances the MS5611 reads occur too fast, rendering the temperature field useless and driving altitude subsequently into a wrong scaling.

Issue currently exists on commit 1cebdf6fb2724b94bce53f37a516dfc913fae994

ms5611: single read
ms5611: pressure:      973.4400
ms5611: altitude:       336.8372
ms5611: temperature:  31.0300
ms5611: time:        125460308
ms5611: periodic read 0
ms5611: pressure:      959.3200
ms5611: altitude:       458.9900
ms5611: temperature:  24.3900
ms5611: time:        125997823
ms5611: periodic read 1
ms5611: pressure:      959.5800
ms5611: altitude:       456.7276
ms5611: temperature:  24.3900
ms5611: time:        126504193
ms5611: periodic read 2
ms5611: pressure:      959.6900
ms5611: altitude:       455.7706
ms5611: temperature:  24.3900
ms5611: time:        127010563
ms5611: periodic read 3
ms5611: pressure:      973.3300
ms5611: altitude:       337.7833
ms5611: temperature:  30.2600
ms5611: time:        127528990
ms5611: periodic read 4
ms5611: pressure:      973.4000
ms5611: altitude:       337.1812
ms5611: temperature:  30.2600
ms5611: time:        128035360
ms5611: PASS

title: EEPROM and Baro/Mag bus accesses conflict
body:
The bus accesses of EEPROM and sensors conflict, resulting in the EEPROM failing to attach:

eeprom: failed to initialize NXFFS: Invalid argument

This has to be properly resolved with correct prioritization and transmitting the EEPROM contents in small chunks, to allow the sensors app to still read the sensors in-between.

This is a high-priority issue, as its on the critical path to put master onto the px4dev_new_param implementation and get the systems again flying. Most of the parameters are already registered and porting the access to them is under way.

title: printf() for %f is broken since one of the last merges
body:
Output of tests float:

```

nsh> tests float

--- SINGLE PRECISION TESTS ---
The single precision test involves calls to fabsf(),
if test fails check this function as well.

         success: sinf(0.0f) == 0.0f
         success: sinf(1.0f) == 0.84147f
         success: asinf(1.0f) == 1.57079f
         success: cosf(1.0f) == 0.54030f
         success: acosf(1.0f) == 0.0f
         success: sinf(0.1f) == 0.09983f
         success: sqrt(2.0f) == 1.41421f
         success: atan2f(1.0f, 1.0f) == 0.78539f
         FAIL: printf("%8.4f", 0.553415f) != "  0.5534", result:   0.0g34

--- DOUBLE PRECISION TESTS ---
         success: 1.0111 * 2.0 == 2.0222
         success: (float) 1.55f == 1.55 (double)
         success: sin(0.0) == 0.0
         success: sin(1.0) == 0.84147098480
         success: atan2(1.0, 1.0) == 0.785398
         testing pow() with magic value
           (44330.0 * (1.0 - pow((96286LL / 101325.0), 0.190295)));
         success: result: 0Z8.2293
         FAIL: printf("%8.4f", 0.553415) != "  0.5534", result:   0.0g34

 FAIL: One or more tests failed.
```
